title: Boutonniere Deformity of the Ring Finger in a 45-Year-Old Pianist
clinical_history: A 45-year-old right-handed pianist presents with a 6-week history of progressive deformity and pain in the ring finger of her right hand.  She first noticed the problem after a concert where she played for an extended period.  Initially, she experienced stiffness and mild pain in the finger, which she attributed to overuse.  However, over the following weeks, the finger began to buckle at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and hyperextend at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint, resulting in a Boutonniere deformity.  She reports difficulty playing the piano and performing daily activities such as dressing and grooming.

nprs.affected_area: pain and stiffness at the PIP joint of the ring finger
pain and stiffness at the DIP joint of the ring finger

aggrevating_factors: playing the piano, gripping, grasping, and flexion of the finger
picture: The ring finger is flexed at the PIP joint and hyperextended at the DIP joint, resembling a Boutonniere deformity.
past_history: history of tendonitis in the right wrist, treated with physical therapy and resolved 2 years ago
medical_history: generally healthy, takes occasional acetaminophen for headaches
personal_history: married with two children, works as a pianist and music teacher
imaging: X-rays of the right hand showing no fractures or dislocations, but confirming the Boutonniere deformity
